question.title: How to show my maps website in JavaFX application using WebView?
question.body:
I need to implement a map for my road management project. Something similar to Google Maps but simpler. It is for an academic project. I don't want to use Google Maps API.

I tried using JavaFX WebView. I made an HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code that used MapLibre maps.

HTML

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>MapLibre Map</title>
    <meta name="viewport" content="initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">
    
    <!-- MapLibre GL CSS -->
    <link href="./node_modules/maplibre-gl/dist/maplibre-gl.css" rel="stylesheet">
    
    <!-- Custom CSS -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <div id="map"></div>

    <!-- MapLibre GL JS -->
    <script src="./node_modules/maplibre-gl/dist/maplibre-gl.js"></script>
    
    <!-- Your custom JS -->
    <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

CSS

body, html {
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;
    height: 100%;
}

#map {
    width: 100%;
    height: 100vh;
}

JavaScript

const map = new maplibregl.Map({
    container: 'map',
    style: 'https://api.maptiler.com/maps/streets-v2/style.json?key=uSZHAA0ZFcoLru0ECNJq', // Sample style
    center: [90.4125, 23.8103], // Example: Dhaka
    zoom: 13
});

// Example marker
const marker = new maplibregl.Marker({ color: 'red' })
    .setLngLat([90.4125, 23.8103])
    .addTo(map);

As you can see, I didnt keep it too complex. But yet my WebView control cannot seem to show this. When I try to see this by running the index.html file, I can see it, but when I use it with WebView I don't.

I asked AI, it said that maybe it has something to do with WebGL or that JavaFX is backdated and cant use it or something like that. I have a seperate directory named node_modules as well.

question_comments.body: An (entirely) alternative approach you might want to consider is to use Gluon Maps. This is a JavaFX-native (i.e. no web component) API to OpenMaps. github.com/gluonhq/maps

Have you been able to get your page to work in a web browser app, without any JavFX? If so, post that page’s entire source code. I tried and failed to get the MapLibre QuickStart to work. I do not want to install npm, so I tried using their Unpkg links at bottom of that page. And I tried https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/maplibre-gl/5.6.1/map‌​libre-gl.js and …css <script> elements as well. But in no case do I get their example to work. I get white color across the otherwise empty window. DevTools in browser shows code downloaded.
We need details. Edit your Question to specify the versions of Java and JavaFX. And specify your host OS platform. And link to your mapping framework.

Info on JavaFX Google map support: JavaFX not embedding google maps html. Functionality depends on the map provider, their current map implementation and the JavaFX version used. Very old JavaFX versions were able to show maps, but I wouldn't recommend them. Then for numerous versions (e.g. 18 -> 23) maps didn't work. Newest versions (later than 24) can show maps, so try with the latest JavaFX version and your chosen map provider.

FWIW, I ran a quick test for webView.getEngine().load("https://maps.google.com") using OpenJDK 24.0.1, JavaFX 24.0.2, MacBook Pro 2019 (Intel), OS X 15.5, the map appeared to display and function fine.
One alternative is to call the HostServices.showDocument() to open a link in the default browser which should render the map fine (but it would be external to your app).

Based on previous questions, it seems JavaFX's WebView does not work well with Google Maps or similar technology. Or at least, "recent" versions of JavaFX have this problem. I don't know why this is the case and I don't remember seeing a solution other than, "Don't use JavaFX WebView for this."
